Enjoy sushi of varying levels of sweetness and sourness and different temperatures, in keeping with the traditions.

name: Sushi Kanesaka
description: Owner-chef Shinji Kanesaka is devoted to sushi. He charms his customers as he trains his small army of apprentices. Through the sushi he shapes, Kanesaka conveys his thoughts and understanding of the sea, the fish market, and the work of the artisan. The key to great sushi, he says, is the three-way interplay between topping, vinegared rice, and wasabi. Fixing a keen eye on the condition of the seafood, Kanesaka deftly executes his techniques, harmonising the vinegared rice with each topping.

name: Akasaka Kikunoi
description: Experience the tradition and innovation of Kyoto’s venerable Kikunoi ryotei, but in Tokyo. A watered cobblestone path along with sukiya-style furnishings make for a Kyoto-esque atmosphere. The restaurant serves beautiful, refined Kyoto-style kaiseki. Yoshihiro Murata values the beloved old ceremonial events that make up the Japanese year, as well as the changes brought by the seasons, and incorporates them into the menu.

name: Ginza Fukuju
description: Katsuhiro Onodera is very well versed in traditional Japanese culture, including the Shijo school of knife ceremony and the Omotesenke Fuhaku school of tea ceremony. He may have his feet in tradition, but he’s unfettered by form. The menu is one you’ll remember, harbouring a sense of classic Japanese cuisine while cleverly incorporating Western flavours like truffle and caviar. The Mineoka tofu speciality made from kudzu and milk is based on Edo period literature.

name: Florilège
description: Hiroyasu Kawate uses ingredients from producers he has a relationship with. Investing these ingredients with his sensibilities, he produces one-of-a-kind dishes. He brings out each dish to the table himself and explains it enthusiastically. Talking about past experiences involving the dishes is part of the recipe, and he weaves a story into the dishes as they’re created in the theatre-like open kitchen. The speciality is beef from cows that have calved.

name: Sukiyabashi Jiro Roppongiten
address: 3F, Roppongi Hills Residence B, 6-12-2 Roppongi, Minato-ku, Tokyo, 106-0032, Japan
description: A typical meal might begin with the subtle flavour of white fish, followed by red fish, then chu-toro. After gizzard shad for the sourness come richer flavours such as horse mackerel or shrimp, then mackerel marinated in vinegar to cleanse the palate; uni and anago follow. The changes in flavour are carefully calibrated for the aftertaste that lingers in between. Underneath chef Takashi Ono’s strict demeanour toward his apprentices lies a gentle affection.

name: Glam Enrico Bartolini
address: calle Tron, sestiere Santa Croce 1961, Venice, 30124, Italy
description: The discreet, partially hidden entrance to Palazzo Venart opens into what is a rarity in Venice – a small but charming garden with beautiful furniture. A second garden overlooks the Grand Canal and offers tables where guests can enjoy a coffee or liqueur after their meal. Nestled between these two gardens, a magnificent hotel is home to the restaurant itself, where Michelin-starred chef Enrico Bartolini and the highly talented Donato Ascani, who is at the helm in the kitchen here, offer guests a fine dining experience. The tasting menus feature memorable dishes of extraordinary quality, such as the amazing selection of finger food presented at the beginning of the meal, inspired by traditional Venetian “cicchetti” (a type of tapas) and made from the best seasonal ingredients. Every course is prepared with care and passion and full of intense and harmonious flavours, resulting in cuisine which has made this restaurant a must not only for Venetians but also for visitors from far and wide.

name: San Domenico
description: When we use the word “classic” to describe this recently renovated restaurant, we are referring to its timeless charm from the almost English-style ambience of its dining rooms to the outdoor tables overlooking an attractive square with public gardens. This setting provides the perfect backdrop for a selection of local and Italian dishes, all prepared simply and without excessive frills and with a focus on flavour and guest satisfaction that avoids modern trends. The extensive wine list offers an array of excellent labels. San Domenico is quite simply a landmark in the history of Italian cuisine!

name: Seta by Antonio Guida
description: A complete dining experience offering sophisticated elegance, glamour and beautifully presented cuisine prepared by chef Antonio Guida, who hails originally from Salento but now considers himself Milanese by adoption! Classic and modern, light and yet luxurious, Guida’s cuisine includes meat and fish dishes, combining the flavours of northern Italy with the scents of the south, and exotic influences with traditional Italian ingredients, plus a strong Nordic touch in his use of sauces in many dishes. The wine pairing options are extensive, thanks to a cellar that is home to more than 1 000 labels, and there’s also a good choice of cocktails. In summer, a small number of tables in the inner courtyard provide the perfect setting for the lucky few.

name: Il Piccolo Principe
description: As in a well-orchestrated symphony, chef Giuseppe Mancino, originally from Salerno but with a real admiration for French cuisine, brings together a host of different elements in his dishes, including creativity, elegance, excellent techniques and superb presentation. As well as its à la carte, the restaurant offers tasting menus with a focus on meat, fish and (as a result of recent interest in vegetarian cuisine) vegetables. The impressive wine list boasts a selection of over 800 labels mainly from Tuscany, although wines from other regions and outside Italy also feature, alongside a good choice of champagnes. Last but not least, the restaurant is situated in one of the smartest hotels in town, Il Grand Hotel Principe di Piemonte, which celebrated its centenary in 2022.

name: Il Pagliaccio
address: via dei Banchi Vecchi 129/a, Rome, 00186, Italy
description: The fusion cuisine served at this restaurant tells the story of the chef’s life, blending influences from his experiences and travels around the world to create cuisine that combines Mediterranean flavours with hints of the Orient, something that is quite rare in Italy. Special mention should also be made of the attentive and courteous service overseen by Matteo Zappile, as well as the interesting wine list which boasts a good selection of champagnes.

name: Quattro Passi
address: via Vespucci 13/n, Marina del Cantone, 80061, Italy
description: The story of Quattro Passi is linked to that of Antonio Mellino, one of the most charismatic and exuberant figures in Italian hospitality who, over the years, has established this extraordinarily elegant restaurant following years of dedication and sacrifice and time spent working in France. The beauty of the setting will take your breath away, as will the views of Nerano bay from the terrace and the delicious cuisine showcasing the flavours and colours of Campania. Highly committed to his work front of house, much to the joy and delight of his guests, Antonio has handed over the reins in the kitchen to his son Fabrizio, who has succeeded in the difficult task of continuing to improve what already seemed perfect. The quintessentially Mediterranean cuisine showcases the purity of the extraordinary ingredients used, all of which are skilfully combined in dishes that appear simple but are in fact the result of highly sophisticated techniques, featuring superb natural flavours and harmonious combinations. The wine list is also excellent, with fine recommendations offered by the talented sommelier.

name: Locanda Sant'Uffizio Enrico Bartolini
description: Nestled amid the picturesque hills of the Monferrato region, this restaurant overseen by multi-Michelin-starred Enrico Bartolini sees Gabriele Boffa at the helm in the kitchen, a chef who is young in years but already a real connoisseur of Piedmontese cuisine. With experience in some of the world’s best restaurants behind him, Boffa has accumulated expert knowledge and remarkable technical skills. His cuisine ranges from classic regional dishes interpreted in their purest form – such as his extraordinary agnolotti del plin – to more creative options, which demonstrate a connection with the region, whether in their ingredients or recipes. The setting here is that of an old monastery converted into a smart hotel, with meals served either in an elegant dining room or in the old limonaia (where lemon trees were once stored). The dishes on offer will linger long in the memory, from the generous amuses-bouches to the delicious bread and incredible focaccia, the top-quality meat and much more besides!

name: Enoteca La Torre
description: Situated just outside the Aurelian Walls within the aristocratic Hotel Villa Laetitia, this restaurant boasts an elegant ambience with antique furniture, flowers, columns and stucco decor. The cuisine is as elegant as the setting, with some dishes (such as the huge babà dessert) finished in front of guests at their table. Chef Domenico Stile celebrates his native region of Campania with passion, exuberance and creativity, skilfully using typical Mediterranean ingredients on a menu which also features a few typical Roman specialities. A superb all-round dining experience for food-lovers, complemented by a well-stocked wine cellar offering an excellent selection of pairing options to enhance their meal.

name: Piccolo Lago
address: via Turati 87, al lago di Mergozzo, Fondotoce, 28924, Italy
description: Marco Sacco is the owner-chef of this charming restaurant with a timeless feel. Leaving busy Lake Maggiore behind, you arrive at tranquil Lake Mergozzo where this restaurant offers picture-postcard views of the water from its terrace. The chef’s technical and creative cuisine is showcased in iconic dishes and new options on the reinstated à la carte, while the 7-course “Una piccola Spirale” tasting menu is inspired by the lake yet features ingredients and traditions from around the world. Our inspector highly recommends the Carbonara Au Koque.

name: Gourmetstube Einhorn
description: Occupying a 13C post house, this restaurant is part of the elegant Stafler hotel, which means that there are guestrooms available for those not wanting to drive home after dinner. This intimate gourmet restaurant has just five tables laid out in a romantic Stube decorated with wood that dates back to medieval times. Chef Peter Girtler offers guests just one tasting menu (from which they can choose four, five or six courses) which features an array of creative dishes full of different ingredients and colours and a combination of meat, fish and vegetables.

name: La Madia
address: corso Filippo Re Capriata 22, Licata, 92027, Italy
description: As well as shining a spotlight on Sicily’s top-quality ingredients, Pino Cuttaia does his best to create dishes that are easily accessible to all. His cuisine aims to awaken our culinary memories, focusing on homely flavours and traditional recipes. “Memory is the secret ingredient in dishes, which all tell a story”, says Cuttaia, and he is also found in the dining room explaining this to his guests. The emotional nostalgia of his cuisine is striking, as his carefully researched and innovative approach. His extraordinary work focuses on his ingredients, which he transforms by highlighting their essential character. The results are often highly original, as in the “Scala dei Turchi” menu which showcases Sicilian meat and fish dishes enabling guests to deepen their knowledge of the island.

name: Miramonti l'Altro
address: via Crosette 34, località Costorio, Concesio, 25062, Italy
description: A French-Italian couple is at the helm in this attractive classic-style villa on the outskirts of Brescia, where a few tables have been laid out in the bay windows overlooking the garden. The friendly, experienced wife oversees the front of house, while her Breton husband is in the kitchen, where he recreates memories of his childhood in France through his use of French ingredients and culinary techniques. The menu also features more obviously Italian and Mediterranean dishes, all of which showcase the delicious, generous flavours that are the hallmark of the cuisine here. There is also an unforgettable cheese trolley with an excellent selection of cheeses in which Italy has the upper hand!

name: Arnolfo
address: viale della Rimembranza 24, Colle di Val d'Elsa, 53030, Italy
description: Moved to Viale della Rimembranza 24, Colle di Val d’Elsa Situated in Italy’s capital of crystal, this restaurant takes its name from the 14C architect Arnolfo di Cambio, whose birthplace is just a few hundred metres from here. Arnolfo is first and foremost a family business, which gives it a friendly, welcoming ambience. Guests are served delicious seasonal specialities that are typical of the region, on a menu that showcases a wide variety of ingredients with a range of flavours (sweet, bitter, sharp and crunchy). Chef Gaetano Trovato travels all over the region in search of the best producers to ensure that his ingredients are of the highest quality. From these carefully selected ingredients, he creates cuisine that is respectful of Tuscan traditions while also adding his own touch of creativity and personality. Although some dishes are influenced by Sicilian culinary traditions, the chef’s favourite dish is pigeon, for which he will always find space on the menu!

name: D'O
description: The focus at this restaurant is on local ingredients and simple preparation, showcased on four tasting menus (Esattezza, Armonia, Molteplicità, andLeggerezza , the restaurant’s “green” menu) which reflect the past and present of chef Davide Oldani’s professional culinary career. Situated on the outskirts of Milan, in a simple, modern dining room which seems to jut out into the piazza thanks to its large windows, the restaurant serves as a backdrop for “pop” cuisine which is accessible and always manages to retain a sustainable focus – ingredients are used to the full and there’s no food waste. An extensive wine list completes the picture.

name: L'Olivo
description: A huge, elegant dining room where candlelight and lamps highlight every decorative detail and where guests dine in comfort on light cashmere sofas and armchairs in a relaxing and stylish atmosphere. In the kitchen, chef Andrea Migliaccio from Ischia is a standard-bearer for creative, elegant and sophisticated Mediterranean cuisine.The principles that guide this chef’s work are simple: innovation and tradition, new dishes and reinterpreted regional classics, plus a careful selection of the best ingredients that the Mediterranean has to offer. L’Olivo’s outdoor terrace has been completely renovated so that it forms a harmonious extension of the dining room, creating the impression of a vast space extending into the horizon. p>The wine list focuses on the region while also including renowned labels from elsewhere in Italy and further afield.

name: La Peca
description: A restaurant with a warm, contemporary-style design, enhanced by carefully chosen decor such as charming centrepieces on the tables (the work of the female owner), modern paintings on the walls and comfortable chairs designed by Philippe Starck. This restaurant’s many attractions include an elegant, dedicated smoking room on the ground floor, where guests can enjoy top-quality spirits accompanied by a selection of the best cigars from around the world. Nicola Portinari creates highly personalised cuisine, with influences from the Veneto and further afield, especially in the cooking methods that he uses. The dessert menu deserves a special mention, thanks to its extensive choice (unusual in a restaurant of this standard), which is complemented by an array of home-made ice creams and sorbets. A superb all-round dining experience, which is further enhanced by the restaurant’s excellent wine list.

name: Acquolina
description: Located on the ground floor of the centrally located luxury The First Roma hotel, with its elegant atmosphere and decor of original artwork, paintings and sculptures, Acquolina serves fish-based dishes with a Mediterranean flavour and an added twist of creativity. The perfectly balanced recipes include delicious options such as “mullet, duck heart, juniper and cherry” and “mushroom, snail and parsley”. The service is of the same high standard as the food, with staff offering efficient and discreet assistance throughout the meal. An excellent wine selection completes the picture.

name: Antica Osteria Cera
description: One of Italy’s most famous addresses for fish and seafood, this restaurant offers an extensive menu featuring classic house favourites alongside a growing list of more modern options. In this elegant, modern and minimalist-style setting (despite the name, don’t expect a trattoria-style ambience here!) enjoy raw fish dishes and grilled options alongside more traditional, often Venetian, specialities such as the Venetian-style spider crab, and classic Italian dishes such as the warm steamed fish salad and the fritto misto (mixed fried fish). In all dishes, the excellent quality of the ingredients shines through. There’s also an excellent wine list, with a particular focus on white wines.

name: Antica Corona Reale
description: Situated between the Langhe and Monviso, this long-established restaurant celebrated its 200th anniversary a few years ago. Run by the Vivalda family for five generations, the restaurant was first established as a dairy farm before gaining a well-earned reputation for its cuisine. Owner-chef Gian Piero creates top-quality menus featuring expertly prepared, colourful and aromatic dishes. Popular with food-lovers from Italy and abroad, Cervere is also a point of reference for many local businesses who supply the restaurant with capon, guinea fowl, veal, Carmagnola peppers, porcini mushrooms and much more besides. In summer, dine alfresco in the shade of a beautiful pergola among colourful flowers and a small fountain. Two small private rooms are available for intimate dinners, one of which is in the wine cellar surrounded by legendary bottles of wine.

name: Santa Elisabetta
description: Thought to date back to Byzantine times, the Torre della Pagliazza has had many uses over the centuries, including housing a women’s prison in the 12C. Today it is home to one of the most interesting gourmet restaurants in Florence, where chef Rocco De Santis creates imaginative Mediterranean cuisine which is precise and full of flavour, with influences from his native Campania and an emphasis on fish and seafood. At lunchtime, a tasting menu of just three courses (“Carte Blanche”) is also available. As there are just a few tables here, guests are advised to book well in advance.

name: Taverna Estia
address: via Guido De Ruggiero 108, Brusciano, 80031, Italy
description: Relaxing niches separated by “walls” of jasmine and a delightful herb garden at the entrance greet guests when they arrive at this restaurant, where the dining room has a welcoming and personalised feel with a mix of modern and rustic decorative features. Taverna Estia always meets expectations with its typical regional cuisine, which is refined, elegant and complex thanks to the skill and creativity of the chef here. There are three tasting menus: one focused on meat dishes, a second on fish and seafood, and a third (the most creative and exciting) where the chef gives free rein to his imagination in creations such as the delicious rice and seaweed chips. The wine list is as impressive as the cuisine, featuring well-known labels from Campania and elsewhere in Italy alongside bottles from small wineries discovered over the years. There’s also an extensive selection of European mineral waters, plus typical Neapolitan Moka-pot coffee for those who like their coffee strong.

name: Magnolia
address: via Pelliciano 37, loc. Montilgallo, Longiano, 47020, Italy
description: Situated in the elegant Relais Villa Margherita, an 18C villa converted into a stylish residence with just six guestrooms, verdant grounds, and a swimming pool, Magnolia is the two-Michelin-starred gourmet restaurant run by Alberto Faccani. There are two tasting menus here (dishes can also be chosen à la carte): one dedicated to Faccani’s classic favourites; the other featuring new dishes created by a chef who is constantly experimenting and evolving. Faccani’s cuisine is complex and sophisticated, combining different approaches and ingredients which result in full, satisfying and enticing flavours.

name: Terra
description: Terra is reached via a road that runs uphill through the woods, a magical landscape that is reflected in its cuisine – a real love letter to the mountains! In this elegant and unusual restaurant, which combines modern features with a profusion of wood and wines exhibited in a glass-walled room suspended over the dining room, the cuisine is served on a long tasting menu made up of small, delicious courses that are perfectly prepared and show remarkably impressive techniques, one delightful surprise following another. Almost all the ingredients come from the region (many from the Sarentino valley itself), and there’s a particular focus on aromatic herbs – the chef is a real expert. As the restaurant is in a somewhat isolated location, you make like to take advantage of the beautiful guestrooms to round off your experience and avoid driving after dinner.

name: Krèsios
description: Krèsios – one of the names given to Bacchus or Dionysus – is run by chef Giuseppe Iannotti. This welcoming country house boasts an attractive mix of traditional and modern decor, with its stone walls, rustic atmosphere and wine cellar carved out of the tufa rock. In the latter, a selection of 2 000 labels is overseen by talented sommelier Alfredo who is always on hand to recommend the best wine to accompany your meal. The open-view kitchen offers views of the chef and his excellent team at work, busy preparing creative, personalised dishes which are often stylish and always out of the ordinary, all presented on just one tasting menu (its name “Mr Brown” is a reference to Quentin Tarantino’s film “Reservoir Dogs”). Iannotti’s cuisine is based on his philosophy of research and imagination, with touches of improvisation and ingredients of the highest quality from around the world. Three welcoming guestrooms are also available.

name: Castel finedining
description: Situated within the exclusive Castel hotel, this restaurant occupies a curve-shaped dining room with just a few tables arranged in front of floor-to-ceiling windows offering stunning views of Merano, the valley and the Alpine peaks in the distance. Gerhard Wieser’s precise, technical and carefully prepared cuisine is equal to the fine setting, featuring a selection of classic dishes with an international influence alongside specialities from the Alto Adige. An excellent selection of wine and highly professional service complete the picture, making this an all-round dining experience to remember.

name: Agli Amici
description: Serving signature cuisine, Agli Amici is one of the leading restaurants in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, a border region of diverse cultural influences that is bursting with top-quality ingredients. Many of these ingredients are showcased on the three tasting menus (one vegetarian) served here, from which guests can also choose individual dishes à la carte. Chef Emanuele Scarello makes full use of the region’s abundant produce, an inexhaustible array of ingredients from pastureland, mountains and vegetable gardens, which he transforms into culinary works of art. His vegetables are grown by local gardeners, while his fresh fish is nearly always sourced from Grado market. Front of house, Michela is responsible for a young and harmonious professional team of staff. Following recent refurbishment, the restaurant is now even more attractive than before.

name: Harry's Piccolo
description: Thanks to its hushed ambience, Harry’s Piccolo is an ideal choice for a romantic dinner or a business meal, with fine cuisine prepared by chefs Matteo Metullio and Davide De Pra. Despite their youth, these two chefs demonstrate plenty of ability and creativity, serving dishes that showcase local meat, fish and seafood, and seasonal vegetables, as well as hints of the Orient, in this elegant setting. One of their signature dishes is the Harrysotto - risotto cooked with tomato water, plankton and garnished with basil cream and capers. The wine list focuses particularly on the region, while also featuring some top-quality labels from outside Italy including a good selection of sparkling wines such as the renowned Krug champagne. Added bonuses are the friendly service, and an outdoor space for an aperitif or after-dinner drink with views of one of Italy’s most beautiful squares.

name: Torre del Saracino
description: The name of this restaurant refers to its location in a 13C fortified tower, one of many dotted along this coastline. Here, guests can savour a pre-dinner drink or a coffee, before moving into the more classic, elegant dining rooms. Looking across at Vesuvius, the word volcano comes to mind when describing chef Gennaro Esposito – he positively explodes with ideas, creating dishes and anticipating culinary trends as only a few chefs can, trends which are then picked up and copied by other restaurants. His Mediterranean cuisine makes much use of ingredients from Campania, some with combinations that sound strange on the menu but in the hands of Esposito reveal themselves to be full of harmonious contrasts. He uses the simplest fish and seafood (such as horse mackerel, grouper and albacore tuna) in his carefully prepared recipes which feature on tasting menus that showcase his culinary philosophy to the full. His raw fish dishes provide a feast for the eyes and the palate – the fish is sourced directly from local fishermen who bring the best of their catch here. The wine list includes renowned labels and fine vintages; a visit to the historic wine cellar in the tower basement is highly recommended.

name: Madonnina del Pescatore
description: It’s almost forty years since the Madonnina opened in 1984, yet chef Moreno Cedroni has not lost the creative touch that has resulted in him becoming one of the most influential chefs of his generation. Year after year, eating at La Madonnina remains a novelty: the menu succeeds like no other in reflecting past traditions and future culinary trends, especially in its fish and seafood dishes. The chef’s wife Mariella oversees the excellent service front of house, while this wonderful couple’s commitment to their cuisine is also demonstrated by their vegetable garden situated almost right on the beach, which provides vegetables infused with the salty sea air – a brilliant idea that represents their strong connection to the land. The wine list features a popular selection of French sparkling wines.

name: Casa Perbellini
description: Almost hidden in a charming small house overlooking Piazza San Zeno, also home to the famous basilica of the same name, Casa Perbellini boasts an elegant yet relaxing ambience, where guests can watch the chefs at work in the open-view kitchen. There are three tasting menus available, including a vegetarian option, with some flexibility for guests who prefer à la carte dining. Whether you choose fish, meat or vegetables, all the dishes are cooked to perfection, balanced in flavour and beautifully presented. Special mention must be made of the excellent service charmingly overseen by Barbara, as well as of the superb wine list which includes an extensive selection of French wines, of which both the sommelier and owner-chef Giancarlo are huge fans.

name: St. George by Heinz Beck
description: This restaurant boasts an elegant dining room with a vaguely British feel, as well as a terrace for summer dining overlooking a lush garden with an infinity pool and views of the Strait of Messina and the Sicilian and Calabrian coasts in the distance. Since the summer of 2022, Salvatore Iuliano has been at the helm in the kitchen here, creating dishes which are modern and creative in style. This young yet serious chef is both talented and professional, having previously demonstrated his ability to manage a team with excellent results during his time as sous-chef here.

name: Villa Feltrinelli
description: Villa Feltrinelli, a magnificent Art Nouveau villa full of individual charm and beautifully maintained over the years, provides the perfect setting for chef Stefano Baiocco’s creative cuisine. A romantic aperitif on the lakeside is highly recommended, after which guests can enjoy the “blind” tasting menu which has been served here since 2021. This technically expert and imaginative chef, equally at ease with meat and fish, demonstrates his true culinary ability in his use of vegetarian ingredients. His skill in the use of herbs and edible flowers is unequalled, as demonstrated in his highly original salad with over a hundred different herbs and more than 20 flowers, all of which come from the property’s own bucolic kitchen garden. In short, this restaurant has it all – delicious cuisine, striking architecture, breathtaking beauty and a nostalgic, timeless and relaxing ambience.

name: Bracali
description: The small, fairly ordinary village of Ghirlanda in the heart of the Colline Metallifere is home to an unexpectedly elegant restaurant, where chef Francesco creates highly original and personalised cuisine. His focus is mainly on meat dishes, which are full of contrasting yet harmoniously balanced flavours (vegetable-meat, fatty-acidic, sweet-sour, soft-crunchy etc). Francesco’s brother Luca takes care of the wine and front of house with skill and dedication; the wine list is extensive and well structured, subdivided into two separate sections (Italy and the rest of the world). Bracali has established a partnership with the local diocese, including helping with the social integration of refugees and managing food waste. In the dining room, works of art are exhibited on a rotation basis and listed in a catalogue.

name: daní maison
description: “Home, family, tradition” is the motto of daní maison, the restaurant opened by Nino Di Costanzo in his old family house surrounded by the fertile vegetable gardens of Ischia. A small, romantic dining room surrounded by beautiful herb-scented Mediterranean maquis acts as the backdrop for the delicious cuisine which has made this chef famous, thanks to his creativity and technical expertise. For many years, Di Costanzo has experimented with combinations that showcase every single ingredient in a dish, which are intended to be instantly recognisable however complex the recipe. Although there are no sea views here, it is fish (from around the island and neighbouring Procida) that takes pride of place on the menu in dishes that are memorable for their stunning presentation. Book the chef’s table where you’ll have the best view of the chef at work, although you can also catch glimpses of the activity in the kitchen from elsewhere in the dining room. The recently opened Salumeria bistro at the garden entrance serves traditional dishes from Campania in a small dining room, as well as outdoors on its shady terrace. Be careful as the access road to the restaurant is particularly narrow.

name: Caino
description: Inextricably connected to the land around it, this restaurant has the distinction of having introduced the world to the cuisine of the Maremma, reinterpreted in elegant, contemporary and often creative fashion by skilful chef Valeria Piccini, now ably assisted by her son Andrea. The philosophy of this great cook is based on a belief that guests should know exactly what they are eating, which means that she avoids techniques that are excessive or too elaborate and always prepares her food using the best possible ingredients. Situated in a small, picturesque village in the hills, Caino stands not far from the romantic Piazza del Castello, which is well worth a visit.

name: Duomo
description: Chef Ciccio Sultano provides an intimate portrait of Sicily at this restaurant situated just a stone’s throw from the Duomo di San Giorgio in the heart of Ibla, one of the most charming historic centres in Sicily. Drawing on his deep knowledge of the region, he creates some of the island’s most spectacular cuisine, which is served in comfortable, intimate dining rooms. There are two tasting menus, from which dishes can also be chosen à la carte.

name: Tre Olivi
description: Housed in the Savoy Beach Hotel, yet with its own entrance, Tre Olivi burst on to the culinary scene after being awarded two Michelin stars when previously it held none, so impressed were our inspectors by the skilful chef here. Today Giovanni Solofra works hard to consolidate his success, continuing to improve and always with a focus on the Cilento region. Originally from Torre Annunziata, not too far from here, this chef has fallen in love with the Cilento and its extraordinary ingredients, such as buffalo milk, Menaica anchovies and heritage flour varieties. Particular mention should be made of the various types of bread, including an outstanding brioche. Meals are served in an elegant, contemporary-style dining room adorned with decorations that pay tribute to olives.

name: Il Luogo di Aimo e Nadia
description: This long-established restaurant, which opened nearly 60 years ago, now offers two generous tasting menus, one with a seasonal focus, the other showcasing top-quality ingredients from all over Italy. The atmosphere here is decidedly contemporary and yet also simple, providing the perfect backdrop for dishes prepared with a professional approach which is accessible to all. The cuisine is inspired by Italian traditions which are reinterpreted in dishes that allow the quality of the ingredients to shine through.

name: Stand
description: A central glass-walled kitchen is the focal point of this eye-catching modern restaurant; a dining room sits either side, and there’s a chatty buzz to the room – helped along by the personable service team. The two experienced chef-owners are proud of their Hungarian roots and skilfully reinvent and modernise classic Hungarian dishes using a wide range of techniques. Wonderful flavours and textures abound, and build steadily throughout the meal. When it comes to wine, look to the Hungarian options – there are some great sweet Tokajis on the list.

name: Platán Gourmet
description: Your evening starts with an aperitif and snacks on the terrace beneath the castle, before you are shown through to a barrel-vaulted cellar where four tables sit in front of the open kitchen. Here, the team work with calm efficiency and meticulous precision to create highly sophisticated dishes which are packed with deep, well-balanced flavours and bags of personality; choose 4, 6 or 8 courses, with wines to match. For the full experience, stay the night in one of the nearby bedrooms and make the most of their spa.

name: Yu Zhi Lan
address: No. 1, 24 Changfa Street, Chengdu, China Mainland
description: This low-key dining concept doesn’t need a sign. The owner-chef Lan Guijun is a local legend who took Sichuanese to the level of haute cuisine so gourmands will always find their way here. The rooms exude rustic charm, dotted by ceramic art and pottery made by the chef himself. Before you can taste his elegant, elaborate multi-course meal that brings out the ingredients’ natural flavours, you need to book a table with a deposit.

name: Maison Wenger
address: Rue de la Gare 2, Le Noirmont, 2340, Switzerland
description: The drive through picture postcard landscapes is not only delightful, at the end you will be rewarded by the excellent menu of this elegant restaurant in a pretty country village. The owner-chef Jérémy Desbraux, who worked with Franck Giovannini at Crissier for a spell, has a knack for imparting incredible depth and flavour to classical dishes. Every dish is perfectly balanced, with neither too little nor too many enticing aromas. The ingredients are naturally first class, and some are sourced locally. The lunchtime menu is also very enticing. The service is unstuffy yet professional and the wines of the moment are particularly excellent. A handful of luxuriously appointed guestrooms for overnight stays.

name: Da Vittorio
address: Via Johannes Badrutt 11, Saint Moritz, 7500, Switzerland
description: If you happen to be in St Moritz in the winter season, then take advantage of the opportunity to dine at the stylish yet cosy restaurant of the Carlton Hotel, in its serene location overlooking the lake. During the winter months, a fantastic kitchen team serves up precise and light Italian cuisine that steers clear of fuss and frills. The focus lies squarely on the produce that goes into the dishes. Some of the brilliantly prepared specialties from the parent restaurant in Brusaporto, Lombardy, make an appearance, including, of course, the signature pasta dish, paccheri alla Vittorio, but also many fish dishes, such as crudo d'Amare, raw fish and shellfish. Plus, an excellent front-of-house team: confident, charming and classy!

name: 7132 Silver
description: The 7132 Hotel is a real heritage building and akin to a place of pilgrimage for design and architecture fans. Silver, with its stylishly elegant interior and, above all, Mitja Birlo's cuisine, will also turn your head. Excellent ingredients and sophisticated techniques go into each course of his set menu, which is stamped with his own distinctive style. The professional front-of-house staff have plenty of good wine recommendations. The chefs also bring the food to your table, sometimes finishing off the dishes there – they talk you through it all, also providing information on the high-quality ingredients. The team is bubbling over with enthusiasm and expertise – sophisticated but by no means stuffy. If you sit at the large window front, you get a view of the Hörnli and Tomül mountains. Or perhaps you would rather book the chef's table in the kitchen?

name: Einstein Gourmet
description: Without a doubt one of the top restaurants in Switzerland, thanks to Sebastian Zier and Richard Schmidtkonz plus their dedicated kitchen team. They prepare a veritable culinary fireworks display, skilfully putting their own stamp on a salvo of courses. Creativity is injected into the full-bodied and expressive dishes, which are built on classical foundations and organised into a set menu. In addition, you can look forward to excellent service, courtesy of a team that includes a sommelier who has a great repertoire of first-class wines at his fingertips, in a selection that shows a penchant for Bordeaux and Switzerland.

name: La Brezza
description: This elegant place dedicated to modern cuisine is part of the impressive Tschuggen Grand Hotel, perched at 1 800m above sea level. Young chef Marco Campanella dazzles with astute combinations, clean flavours and a skilful touch when it comes to deploying acidity. His dishes are sophisticated but never ostentatious; rather, they are light and accessible. The produce is consistently top-notch in terms of freshness and quality. Two set menus are served: "Inspiration" and "Moving Mountains". The latter is completely vegan and reflects the latest research in the field of nutrition. The service is always friendly and professional. During the summer season, Marco Campanella cooks at the restaurant of the same name in Ascona.

name: Widder Restaurant
description: In the chic fine dining restaurant of the luxurious boutique hotel of the same name, head chef Stefan Heilemann and his team skilfully bridge the gap between classic and modern cuisine, throwing in a few international influences for good measure. The dishes are well thought out, technically precise and replete with subtle contrasts. They also use home-grown ingredients. A four- to six-course set menu is served (vegetarian version also available). You also have the chef's classics on the "Supplements" menu to choose from. Stefano Petta's competent front-of-house team takes a pleasingly relaxed approach when it comes to serving guests. Tip: Reserve the Chef's Table! One floor below is the Widder Bar.

name: IGNIV Zürich by Andreas Caminada
description: Andreas Caminada is the man behind this fabulous new venture in the Marktgasse Hotel, situated in the heart of the historical district on the right bank of the Limmat. You access the tastefully designed restaurant via the beautiful, classically styled bar (where they will be happy to serve you an aperitif). A set menu proposes courses for sharing; supplementary dishes can be ordered à la carte. Talented young chef Daniel Zeindlhofer sticks to the IGNIV philosophy and combines it with his own ideas. His cuisine is complex but accessible – this is food that puts a smile on your face! From the excellent wine list, opt for the wines from the Zurich region, available by the glass. First-class service is provided by the charming and accomplished front-of-house team led by Ines Triebenbacher. To round off the experience, the "Candy Store" is typical of the IGNIV experience!

name: The Restaurant
description: The Dolder Grand luxury hotel (a former "Kurhaus" or health resort, built in 1899) boasts a truly fantastic location above Zurich – even the driveway to the garage is impressive! If possible, book a window seat in the hotel's chic fine dining restaurant so you can savour the magnificent view of the city while you eat. The huge glass wine cabinet also draws the eye. Chef Heiko Nieder's elaborate and detail-oriented cooking is modern and creative but equally classical. This Schleswig-Holstein native always puts the (top-notch) produce centre stage and cooks up fantastically harmonious compositions. His vegetarian alternatives are no less impressive. Tip: the five-course "amuse-bouche menu", served at lunchtime, allows you to sample a good cross-section of the food.

name: roots
description: You might not expect to find such an outstanding fine dining restaurant in a congress and event venue such as the Rhypark. The location next to the Dreirosenbrücke, directly on the Rhine, is superb, the interior is chic and modern, and the terrace is wonderful. Then there is the creative cuisine of Pascal Steffen and his team. The five- to nine-course set menu may have a predominantly vegetarian slant (try, for example, the "roots garten" – a signature dish), but fish and meat are also on offer. The chefs take an appealingly pared-down approach, which does not at all detract from the depth and sophistication of their dishes showcasing excellent produce from the region. Restaurant manager Jonas Brucker oversees the highly accomplished yet delightfully relaxed and informal front-of-house team.

name: Anne-Sophie Pic
description: The famous French chef presides over the fate of this cutting-edge gourmet venue in the Beau-Rivage Palace Hotel, facing the tranquil waters of Lake Geneva. Ms Pic has entrusted the culinary score to the competent hands of the restaurant’s former sous-chef, youthful Kevin Vaubourg. A change of cast but the house signature dishes remain firm fixtures on the menu. Diners can be reassured that the demanding inventive streak that has ever linked the Pic name to high-flying Gallic gastronomy continues to thrive here. A culinary masterclass throbbing with flavour.

name: Ecco St. Moritz
description: Ascona in summer, St Moritz in winter? This is how top chef Rolf Fliegauf and his team do it, changing locations according to the seasons. In the warm season they cook at Ecco on Lake Maggiore and as the snow settles on the ground they migrate to the Engadine valley, to the fine dining restaurant of the Giardino Mountain hotel. You can sense the energy and expertise of this Swabian-born chef – this is cuisine you can rely on! He wins over diners with the light and playful touch he brings to his modern dishes. Throughout the four to seven courses of the set menu, the focus is on the top-notch ingredients. Your highly committed and charming host, Jenifer Fliegauf, is the driving force behind the extremely friendly front-of-house team, ensuring her guests receive attentive and unflappable service.

name: Magdalena
description: The adage here is "raw, rugged, regional". Head chef Dominik Hartmann (whose CV includes a stint with Andreas Caminada) and his kitchen team delight with an extremely expressive and technically excellent aromatic cuisine that is rich in contrasts. He homes in on regional produce, and small-scale producers are his go-to suppliers. The modern and seasonal surprise menu comprises five to seven courses, with five courses for Sunday lunch. Having a penchant for vegetables, the chef has switched to 100% vegetarian cooking here. Inside the refined, upscale restaurant (at its best at sunset!), you only have to glance out of the floor-to-ceiling windows at the village, mountains and lake to understand why this young trio chose to fulfil their dream of running their own restaurant in this spot!

name: Pavillon
description: As you would expect in this luxurious grand hotel dating back to 1844, everything at Pavillon, too, is the height of style and premium quality. The restaurant is located in a building designed by architect Pierre-Yves Rochon, with floor-to-ceiling windows and a light-filled rotunda. Chef Maximilian Müller cooks up modern-inspired dishes rooted in French cuisine. Fabulous ingredients are the focus. There is a small à la carte selection and a set menu (plus a vegetarian version) that gives you a good overview of the cuisine. To go with your food, there are wines from their own vineyard. Very professional service from a classical front-of-house team that includes an excellent sommelier.

name: Gasthaus Zur Fernsicht - Incantare
description: Incantare is the Italian verb for "delight", which precisely describes the effect of the modern cuisine served at this chic restaurant. Tobias Funke and Martin Weber preside in the kitchen, creatively and harmoniously combining flavours, textures, fruit and acidity. They place great value on sourcing seasonal ingredients from the region and using environmentally friendly and resource-conserving producers. Some of the vegetables are grown especially for this establishment. The patisserie is rather special: they do their own thing, entirely dispensing with white sugar, for example. The exclusive wine pairings are also worth mentioning, with around 1 000 labels to choose from; the alcohol-free alternatives may also pique your interest. Extremely charming, competent and ever-attentive service. And then there's the great view!

name: IGNIV by Andreas Caminada
description: This stylish restaurant in a historical vaulted room inside the Grand Resort Bad Ragaz showcases a concept that was devised by none other than celebrated chef Andreas Caminada: an elaborate, creative "fine dining sharing experience". In keeping with the name (igniv is a Romansh word meaning "nest"), the focus is on the well-being of guests and the pleasure of communal dining. First-rate ingredients are used to create a very special set menu, each course of which is made up of several small dishes – all designed for sharing. Shored up by a competent sommelier, the charming service team is second to none. The outstanding wine list features top-notch wines, often regional, that are available by the glass. Last but not least, the impressive Candy Store awaits you.

name: RICO'S
description: Rico Zandonella's restaurant stands out from the crowd. Charming, cosy, colourful and packed with art – a tastefully eclectic mix of styles and highly individual decorative details. In addition, the service is pleasingly laid-back and professional. Then there is the food, which, with its colourful presentation, mirrors the offbeat flair of your surroundings. This is modern and creative fare, with classic and Mediterranean influences; needless to say, only the best ingredients make it onto your plate. To accompany these great dishes, choose from the nicely curated wine list with a particularly appealing selection of labels from Switzerland and France. A lunch menu is available Tue-Fri. A tip for those looking for a venue for private events: you can book Rico's Privé.

name: Domaine de Châteauvieux
description: The owner-chef, Philippe Chevrier, has treated this stylish, local institution, off the beaten tourist track, oozing in charm and idyllically surrounded by vineyards, to a youthful makeover. All the more reason to discover this culinary landmark in the vicinity of Geneva. Assisted by a seasoned, white-jacketed brigade, Philippe crafts quintessential French cuisine, ranging from modern to classical, based on outstanding seasonal produce and immediately identifiable flavours. Seamless, attentive service and a mouth-watering wine list. Book yourself into one of the exquisitely decorated guestrooms to recover from this culinary experience in style.

name: Taverne zum Schäfli
description: Even the gorgeous exterior of the 300-year-old Riegelhaus does not prepare you for the level of sophistication of the cuisine that awaits you here. Chef-patron Christian Kuchler is a master of the classics, as is borne out by his dishes, which are prepared from excellent ingredients that focus on taste rather than gimmickry – and that includes the excellent sauces! In addition, there is a wine list that leaves hardly anything to be desired: wonderful German Rieslings, great regional wines, red wines from France and Italy with an impressive range of vintages... It is delightful to sit in the tasteful and cosy dining rooms or out on the charming terrace. First-class service rounds off the experience perfectly. And should you wish to stay overnight, they have some lovely guestrooms.

name: Stucki - Tanja Grandits
description: The name "Stucki" is a tribute to Tanja Grandits's legendary predecessor, Hans Stucki. A chic ambience prevails in this historical villa; the stylish, relaxed and professional service comes courtesy of an experienced and ever-present front-of-house team that is headed up by Grégory Rohmer. As for the food, you will be able to experience Tanja Grandits's inimitable culinary style, characterised by her penchant for subtly incorporating flowers, leaves and colours. She conjures up fresh and elegant dishes that are bursting with skilfully combined flavours. Diners never feel overwhelmed – her creations never tip into overkill. Nine-course evening set menu (vegetarian possible); at lunchtime a shorter menu is also available. In summer, the garden terrace is a true oasis! Tip: the small shop sells tea, spices, condiments etc.

name: Ecco
description: Situated in the Giardino hotel, the first dining room at this restaurant boasts an open-view kitchen and a wall adorned with more than eleven thousand rose petals, so beautiful that they seem real. From here, you pass into a second dining area comprising a veranda overlooking a splendid garden with a small lake, which transforms into a single outdoor space in summer. Wherever you choose to eat, the setting is idyllic. Chef Rolf Fliegauf’s cuisine focuses on modern dishes with classic roots, including iconic and highly recommended recipes such as the delicious “braised shoulder of lamb (from Sisteron) with green asparagus, spring herbs and salted lemon”. The tasting menu offers a choice of four or seven courses, while the wine list features a number of refined labels to satisfy the most discerning of wine-lovers. Excellent service.

name: Skin's - the restaurant
description: It is absolutely worth coming here for a meal. The restaurant is located in a former factory, next to Skinmed clinic (hence the name). Past a small bar on the ground floor, a lift takes you up to the first floor, where you will be seated at a beautiful wooden table in a chic, modern interior done out in plush dark tones and defined by clear lines. In the fully visible open kitchen, Kevin Romes's team prepares modern dishes inspired by cuisines from around the world, but also by produce from Switzerland. From the amuse-bouche to the patisserie, the bar is set very high. Down-to-earth and charming, the professional service team guides you through the evening with aplomb. They will also be happy to recommend a drink from the well-thought-out non-alcoholic accompaniments as an alternative to wine.

name: Sens
description: Not far from the beautiful Hotel Vitznauerhof, this modern restaurant is housed in what was once the boathouse. The location right by the water is fantastic and the terrace with its small "island" is simply magical. This all makes for a maritime atmosphere, complete with wonderful sunsets! The cuisine is also rather special: not only do they use exceptionally good ingredients, they also prepare them intelligently and bring their own ideas into play. Dutchman Jeroen Achtien, who cooked for many years in Jonnie Boer's three-star restaurant, presents a surprise menu that is technically very sophisticated, but unpretentious for all that. Intense flavours are creatively combined in exciting ways and with a truly delicate touch. Guests are treated to a warm reception, and the wine recommendations also hit the mark. End of May until end of summer: pop-up concept "Ibiza Food Studio" (Sun.-Thu.).

name: focus ATELIER
description: The prestigious nature of the Park Hotel Vitznau extends to its restaurant. Led by head chef Patrick Mahler, the kitchen crew cooks up a thrillingly creative set menu that showcases the well-thought-out, detailed preparation and strong sense of finesse. There is no room for cheap showmanship, each dish concentrating instead on excellent ingredients. The wine list verges on overwhelming with its choice of around 35 000 bottles, including first-rate labels in numerous vintages. The service is also excellent: courteous and professional from start to finish, but by no means stiff. The restaurant itself has a chic, upscale design and transparent, light-filled architecture; for the entirely glass-paned pavilion, the name "Atelier" (or workshop) is spot on. On account of its picture-postcard location on Lake Lucerne, complete with panoramic view, the terrace is naturally tempting! Tip: Verlinde Bar.

name: La Brezza
description: Although La Brezza is not a new name amid the different gastronomic options at this exclusive hotel, it is one that is improving year after year, and such “dynamism” undoubtedly brings results. Surrounded by the lush gardens of the Eden Roc hotel, skilled chef Marco Campanella (German by birth but with Italian roots) creates expressive, intense yet delicate cuisine that appeals to the eye and the palate. Carefully selected ingredients (many sourced locally), well-balanced and well-structured menus, plus a wine list that will more than satisfy connoisseurs, who are encouraged to ask for recommendations from the excellent sommelier. Professional service from the young front of house team.

name: Jungsik
description: Touted as a pioneer of modern Korean fine dining, Chef Yim Jung-sik — with his Seoul and New York restaurants - is credited for introducing Korean cuisine to the world with an innovative flair that is entirely his own. What Yim does best is drawing inspiration from the familiar — gimbap, bibimbap, platter of nine delicacies and napa wraps with pork — and creating something unexpected yet surprisingly evocative and authentic. Whimsical desserts, a good wine list and attentive service — Jungsik has it all.

name: Kwonsooksoo
description: Chef Kwon Woo-joong’s homage to tradition is evident in every facet of Kwonsooksoo, even in the name itself (sooksoo is an archaic term for professional cook). Inspired by time-honored methods of cooking, Kwon digs deep into his own roots. He tirelessly scours the country for rare finds that best represent each of the seasons and transforms even the most mundane ingredients into something special. What the diners get to experience is passion on a plate, coupled with a good dose of ingenuity.

name: Mingles
description: Chef Kang Min-goo's keen eye for detail shines in Mingles, from the ceramic ware that highlights the beauty of Korean cuisine to the warm luxury of empty space apparent in the interior design. From the beginning, Kang has marched to the beat of his own drum, breaking down barriers by marrying the old with the new, but always with a deep respect for tradition. His journey and evolution continues, with dishes like Abalone and Cabbage Seon and Fish Mandu showcasing the creativity of the chef and his talented team.

name: La Yeon
address: 23F Shilla Hotel, 249 Dongho-ro, Jung-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: Time-honored traditions of Korean cuisine are given a contemporary touch at La Yeon. Located on the 23rd floor of The Shilla Hotel, this refined dining space offers stunning vistas over Namsan Park. It's the detail here that are noteworthy, from the fine tableware to the attentive service. Hansik and wine pairings elevate the dining experience to another level.

name: Joo Ok
address: 3F The Plaza Hotel, 119 Sogong-ro, Jung-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: The name of the restaurant Joo Ok embodies the simple philosophy of Chef Shin Chang-ho, which is to serve dishes that are as exquisite as precious gems. Shin's culinary creations are a testament to how a city's food culture deeply rooted in tradition withstands the test of time. The restaurant's most prized ingredients consist of some 30 different varieties of fermented condiments; shots of house-made vinegar are offered as an aperitif before the meal. The restaurant's celebrated perilla oil is pressed from perilla seed harvested from his family farm in Jinju. Enjoy the great view of one of the most dynamic areas of the city.

name: alla Prima
description: Chef Kim Jin-hyuk continues to attract discerning gourmets with his whimsically creative and modern offerings. His reverence for seasonal ingredients, his attention to balance, and his delicate yet assertive sauces come together like a symphony that pairs well with both wine and sake. The L-shaped counter with ample seating, the gleaming open kitchen, the spacious dining hall, and the private dining room each do their part to make the diners feel comfortable. Be sure to reserve ahead.

name: Kojima
address: 6F Boon the Shop, 21 Apgujeong-ro 60-gil, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea
description: The serene and reposeful space in Kojima allows patrons to concentrate solely on their sushi. A perfect match between shari (rice) and neta (fish topping), replete with the integral taste of the ingredients, the diner’s plump sushi somehow resembles its creator, Chef Park Kyung-jae. Prepared from ingredients that change daily, the sushi has an unadorned and fine taste, that is, seemingly plain yet flavorful and brims with umami. Be sure to make a reservation if you wish to relish the art of Kojima’s elegant items.

name: Soigné
address: #201, 2F Sinsa square, 652 Gangnam-daero, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, 06027, South Korea
description: [This is the new address updated as the restaurant moved.]Meaning “well-groomed” in French, Soigné lives up to its name with its elegant menu, inspired by global cuisine with distinct undertones of Korea’s culinary philosophy. Chef Lee Jun’s creations are both creative and modern, but the local ingredients he uses always take on the starring roles in his meticulously curated “episodes,” each with its own unique color and lyrical flow. Try the suggested wine pairings for the full gustatory experience.

name: Turk Fatih Tutak
address: Bomonti, Cumhuriyet Hacıahmet Silahşör Caddesi, Yeniyol Sokak No:2, Şişli, Istanbul, 34440, Türkiye
description: Fatih Tutak expresses his love for his Turkish terroir. Every day he puts ingredients from his region and produce from local traders on a pedestal. This is a chef who cooks with respect for tradition and what nature has to offer. His predilection for sustainability is reflected, among other ways, in his no-waste approach and use of preservation techniques such as fermentation and dry-ageing. Traditional flavours take on an extra dimension.  Part of his originality lies in his nuanced use of delicate acidic and smoky flavours, with which he puts his own stamp on dishes. Take his preparation of manti, a delicate stuffed pasta; he fills them with rich lamb and serves them alongside a sublime smoked yoghurt cream, tomato tapenade and chilli butter. For dessert, he invites you into the open kitchen of this chic, contemporary establishment. Here you will find yourself in the thick of the action.

name: Blue Hill at Stone Barns
description: The tasting menu offered here echoes the farm’s seasonal best and might very well change the way you think about food. Culinary wunderkind Dan Barber has become a global icon for his zero-waste philosophy, which is expressed all the way down to the bone ash china gracing the tables and kitchen scraps transformed into charcoal. Meals begin with an onslaught of clever bites, mostly vegetables plucked from the property's greenhouses and working farm. The kitchen infuses even the most unlikely ingredients with magic, like zesty green gazpacho paired with surf clam and radicchio; or dry-aged golden beet "steak" adorned with beef-studded jus. A block of Stone Barns honey semifreddo with strawberry compote brings the kitchen's farm-to-fork mantra full circle.

name: Jean-Georges
address: 1 Central Park West, New York, 10023, USA
description: The longevity of Chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten’s flagship is  be due to many factors—a sumptuous setting, a discreet aura and superior French cuisine. Like walking through Business on your way to First Class, you have to pass through buzzy Nougatine to get here. Low-slung chairs and large tables mean you need a certain confidence in your conversational delivery if you wish to entertain the whole table.Dishes showcase everything from attention to detail and impeccable products to thoughtful garnishes and nuanced flavors. The omnivore menu is also appealingly versatile thanks to contemporary accents and classic techniques. Picture charred beets with tamarind and saffron or buttery Wagyu with crispy potato and black truffle to get those taste buds going.

name: Jungsik
description: Jungsik's "New Korean" cuisine leans westwards. Indeed, some of this kitchen's wonderful sauces wouldn’t be out of place at a grand French table, but what is most impressive here is that the Korean elements of the dishes seem to raise them to another level. Bibimbap composed with gochujang, crispy quinoa and tender Wagyu beef tartare will live long in the memory; while the branzino served simply with white kimchi shows that this is also a kitchen with the utmost confidence in the quality of its ingredients.This is cooking that is original, impeccably executed and enormously satisfying. It’s the sort of food that makes you involuntarily nod to yourself while you’re eating. The space is cool, crisp and elegant; the service team sharp, keen and organized.

name: The Modern
description: The Modern is designed to capture the iconic feel of the MoMA in which it is housed. Art enthusiasts can't help ogling at its glorious surrounds; while excellent acoustics facilitating quiet conversations ensure a steady stream of couples and globe-trotters. The kitchen is state of the art, so for a truly special experience book the chef's table inside. The staff perform a veritable ballet as they present diners with such appealingly nuanced dishes as a seed cracker with aged cheddar and butternut squash butter; or eggs on eggs, starring none other than soft-boiled eggs with sturgeon caviar. Turbot roasted on the bone may then arrive alongside rich parmesan cream.Nurse a digestif—and marvel at the timeless sculpture garden view —for serenity embodied.

name: Ko
description: Tucked into an East Village alley, Ko has been the pride and joy of David Chang's culinary empire since opening in 2014. Though it's now under the stewardship of Chef Esther Ha, some things remain unchanged, like the upbeat soundtrack, sleek counter staged around a kitchen with nowhere to hide and a vibe so relaxed that diners might even sing along.Chef Ha brings new ideas to the fore. A sweet potato, slow-roasted until it achieves an almost custardy texture, is served with dashi broth and crispy fried yuba, while a perfectly crisp "cutlet" of panko-breaded mushroom, is paired with an ultra-rich sauce of foie gras and caramelized doenjang. Desserts display irreverent creativity, as in a Bakewell tart made with a sweet tomato jam and served with a juniper-scented whipped cream.

name: Gabriel Kreuther
description: Distinctively housed at the base of the Grace building, this modern dining room happens to be perfect for celebrating special occasions. Dishes reflect global sensibilities with a strong creative edge, as in the langoustine tartare topped with a crispy tuile and enriched with cauliflower cream. Foie gras arrives in myriad guises, perhaps as a seared lobe as rich as custard, surrounded by roasted quince, chestnuts and vanilla gastrique. Old-school luxuries extend right through to the cheese trolley. The cocktail list is dedicated to the history of Bryant Park across the street, while as an homage to the eponymous chef’s Alsatian heritage, the wine selection prominently features rieslings, pinot blancs and gewürztraminers.

name: Aquavit
description: No detail goes unnoticed at this contemporary Swedish beauty, sporting a sleek bar and open kitchen with Chef Emma Bengtsson at the helm. Enjoy the eponymous infused spirit along with bites from one of two tasting menus. Expect glazed earthenware, slate platters and wooden boxes cradling the likes of a medallion of North Sea cod, torched ever so slightly, and accompanied by a light-textured mussel foam and petite wedges of roasted red endive. Lean and tender duck breast sided by a petite block of compressed leg meat is dressed tableside with a beet sauce enriched with duck jus. The meal may end with a composition of green apple and fennel featuring rye cake, apple ice, bitter caramel and whipped, smoked crème fraîche.

name: Aska
description: Eating here is serious business, but happily the place isn’t blighted by a monastic atmosphere—a contented buzz fills the room, helped along by the chefs who deliver the dishes themselves.Chef Fredrik Berselius and his ace team delight diners with their highly accomplished Nordic cuisine. Local products are woven in to the seasonal tasting, and items like prawn shells and venison bones are transformed into luscious sauces that enhance each plating. Dinner is sure to start on a high note, when Danish kingfish crudo crowned by a dollop of Osetra caviar and dressed with a gooseberry and juniper oil vinaigrette is set on the table. New York state trout may be composed with salted white currant and paired with an aebleskiver enriched with trout belly.

name: Atera
description: Counter dining can sometimes mean lots of elbows; fortunately, this one is large enough to ensure you’re sufficiently secluded, while still letting you enjoy the immersive experience. Danish chef Ronny Emborg and team serve up a menu of courses that progress from light and subtle to rich and robust. Things are certainly grown-up here, with such fully realized dishes as a rye cracker piped with ham and topped with crisped chicken skin; or a potato dumpling smartly dressed with parmesan foam. Paper-thin Wagyu shavings may then be enhanced with a pour of hot dried shrimp bouillon and confit quail egg yolk.There may be some tweezer action as the chefs assemble their beguiling plates, but that also means there’s nowhere to hide when food is this precise.

name: Atomix
description: Atomix is one of Manhattan's most desired dining rooms. Secreted away in a Murray Hill brownstone, the room unfolds into a chic bar and a subterranean dining counter sporting dark stone, soothing earth tones and views of the kitchen's inner works.Chef Junghyun Park and his wife Ellia head a team that continues to push the boundaries of modern Korean cooking.  Dishes are delicate, yet satisfying and display extraordinary finesse. Mastery of technique and depth of flavor are seen in the likes of three-day salt-and-nuruk-cured kohlrabi, and rich Japanese butterfish dabbed with XO sauce and served in a froth of white kimchi sauce. The finale perfectly suits the meal, as in rice ice cream set atop Japanese castella and dressed with malted barley syrup and crushed honeycomb candy.

name: Daniel
description: Everyone needs a little pomp and circumstance now and then and, for these grand occasions, there will always be Daniel. This iconic Manhattan dining room now sports a refreshed look featuring custom-made carpeting and bold artwork that beautifully complements the coffered ceilings and signature Bernardaud porcelain chandeliers.Executive Chef Eddy Leroux skillfully executes the four-course seasonal prix-fixe or seven-course tasting menus. East coast crab duo, pairing a tempura soft-shell crab with peekytoe crab meat, and tender lamb chop with minted breadcrumbs, are just two standout dishes. Desserts are works of art, as in the Champagne mango baba, with a mango brandy-moistened sponge cake, green peppercorn custard and peaks of vanilla chantilly.

name: Saga
description: Saga is the crown of 70 Pine Street, a landmark tower that rises over 60 stories. The space is unique and features an open-air balcony where an aperitif can be enjoyed alongside the stunning views. The elegant dining rooms are set with furnishings upholstered in peach and emerald velvet, green marble tables and carved stone accents.Chef James Kent never allows his cuisine to be overshadowed by the setting, however. Along with his talented team, he presents diners with compositions that embrace luxury and urbane inspiration. Caviar and foie gras are on tap, as is seafood with laksa sauce or a dry-aged duck influenced by the chef's Moroccan background that comes complete with griddled flatbread, whipped yogurt flavored with preserved lemon, carrot hummus and harissa.

name: Al Coro
description: Chef Melissa Rodriguez and Jeff Katz are behind this long-awaited spot, and the adage is true: good things do come to those who wait. Al Coro pours on the drama with old world glamour and live music. The buzzy dining room sets the stage for a kitchen that dances behind the curtain, reveling in the unexpected and sidestepping tradition for the fixed modern Italian menu. A meal here begins with an assortment of antipasti, including smoked ricotta and carrot sformato, and it's clear from those first few bites that this will be an experience to treasure. Pastas are a highlight, with diners choosing from such delights as culurgiones, or Sardinian dumplings. It concludes as it began, with a smattering of bites, from lemon verbena meringue to a rich crostata Barozzi.-

name: Ryō-shō
description: ‘Ryō-shō’ means ‘to surpass the sky’. It could be a statement about chef Makoto Fujiwara’s ambitions. The sukiya-style building, constructed by master artisans, and the paintings, by luminaries of the artistic world, proclaim Fujiwara’s intentions. The fare preserves traditional Japanese cuisine while incorporating Western ingredients through a dialogue with French gastronomy. The very refinement of the cuisine attests to the chef’s humility.

name: Gion Owatari
description: Owner-chef Mahito Owatari’s approach is about bringing original touches to classic cuisine. The wonders he weaves with his ingenious combinations of ingredients make for memorable dining. In spring, white asparagus dressed with kinome miso is used in place of bamboo shoots. The meal ends with an enjoyable zosui made by adding leftover broth and other ingredients to rice. Owatari’s service is cheery and light-hearted, and it shows in the customers' relaxed smiles.

name: VELROSIER
address: 2F, Good Nature Station, 318-6 Inaricho, Shimogyo-ku, Kyoto, 600-8022, Japan
description: In hanakotoba or ‘flower language’, the bellerose (a type of primrose) signifies ‘telling your true feelings to your sweetheart’. Owner-chef Yuji Iwasaki chose it to convey his feelings about gastronomy, and because it’s his birth flower. Foie gras-filled monaka wafer cakes are served with roses for colour and cloves for aroma. The imaginative pan-fried gyoza dish takes apart and reassembles the recipe bit by bit. Iwasaki’s fusion of Chinese and French is an original take.

name: Sushi Harasho
description: Featuring kappo technique, the omakase is something of a story about the path that Ko Ishikawa has taken. Nimono, grilled items, steamed items and other shuko are arranged on antique Kyo ware and on serving dishes by modern artists. The sensibilities he cultivated in general Japanese cuisine can also be seen in the nigiri. The first piece is squid, and the fine scoring brings out the sweetness. He does not use sugar in the vinegared rice, so as to keep the flavours light.

name: Kikunoi Roan
description: In winter, the masterpiece of the house is quail-and-lily-bulb dumpling with black truffle paste; in early summer, there is sorbet of passion fruit and wasabi. Accentuating Japanese cuisine with Western culinary elements is the epitome of ‘tradition and innovation’, as advocated by Kikunoi. At the counter, owner-chef Yoshiharu Murata and the other chefs are a whirlwind of activity. Taking in this bustle while enjoying the fare is the true pleasure of Kikunoi Roan.

name: KAHALA
description: More than half a century since he founded his restaurant, owner-chef Yoshifumi Mori’s inquisitive spirit is as unquenchable as ever. As he seeks out unknown ingredients and new cooking methods, he constantly generates original cuisines. The karasumi somen is piled on lacquer plates he painted himself. The beef millefeuille, served with three flavours, is a masterpiece. ‘I just want to create a little culinary movement of my own’ he says, as he earnestly faces his counter that seats eight.

name: Kenninji Gion Maruyama
description: The culinary journey of owner-chef Yoshio Maruyama is guided by his deep knowledge of the tea ceremony and flower arrangement. His room puts diners at ease; his menu matches the seasons. This is cuisine that reverberates in all five senses. He cooks ingredients from land and sea on a hot stone grill, patiently listening to the sizzle and waiting for the moment they yield up their aroma. Such moments convey the culture and spirt of Japan in ways the eye cannot see and the ear cannot hear.

name: Miyamaso
description: A devotee of the natural beauty of Hanase, Kyoto Prefecture, owner-chef Hisato Nakahigashi uses tsumikusa cuisine (cuisine using wild herbs and vegetables) to convey the food culture of the satoyama (rural villages hugging the hills). He travels into the mountains himself, gathering young herbs in spring and mushrooms in autumn. The edible wild plants in his tsumikusa basket are a signifier of spring. Each season brings its own special joy, like ayu in summer and boar and bear in winter.

name: Numata
description: Owner-chef Kazuya Numata skilfully manipulates the thickness and volume of the batter with a careful eye. He fries his tempura using techniques he developed himself. The menu, which interweaves seasonal ingredients that are just in with those on their way out, sees seafood and vegetables in alternating fashion. Start with the tiger prawn from Numata’s hometown, Amakusa. Possible conclusions to the meal include tendon, tencha, onigiri with shrimp tempura filling and tamagokake-gohan.

name: Koryu
description: The fare of owner-chef Shintaro Matsuo expresses the essence of Naniwa, another name for Osaka. He revels in talking about the culture of enjoying raw fish in Osaka, explaining that for him Naniwa means ‘garden of fish’”, from Osaka Bay being so rich in seafood. Koryu embodies that idea, stocked with seafood from nearby seas. He also explains Naniwa can mean a ‘garden of vegetables’, as the Kawachi Plain on which it sits is renowned as a vegetable-producing region.

name: Tenjimbashi Aoki
description: “Japanese cuisine is an art comprising multiple arts”, observes owner-chef Ryota Aoki. The décor reflects this creed with its harmonious blend of cultural elements. The interior is in the style of sukiya, and the food, served on a mix of antique and modern plates, is arranged to reflect traditional events and seasonal festivals. The star items on the menu are nimono soup, richly flavourful and nutritious, and hassun that pay homage to the classics.

name: Oryori Mitsuyasu
description: The owner-chef visits farmers and gathers vegetables to fire his culinary imagination. Consider the hassun: defying the standard practice of combining ingredients from both ocean and mountain, he serves only vegetables. In spring, sprouting buds are garnished with edible wild plants; in summer, chilled vegetables are cool to both eye and palate; in autumn, chestnuts and mushrooms are the stars of the crop; and in winter, root vegetables are cooked to express the warmth of the good earth.

name: Fujiya 1935
description: Owner-chef Tetsuya Fujiwara aspires to “a dining table of seasons and memories”. Passing through the entrance and moving through to the dining room, the guest is drawn into a unique space that titillates all senses. The fresh, seasonal ingredients are painstakingly selected, and the creative cuisine uses techniques the owner-chef made his own when in Europe. He delivers the food to guests himself and speaks sincerely about the appeal of the ingredients and their background.

name: Yusokuryori Mankamero
description: This long-standing establishment boasts three centuries of history. Renowned as the home of the Ikama school of culinary arts, its traditions have been passed from father to only one child for 10 generations to the current owner-chef, Masakiyo Konishi. The menu consists of yusoku ryori, associated with the seasonal banquets and other annual functions of the Imperial court, and kaiseki based on chakaiseki. Both types of meal conclude with a tai chazuke.

name: Otagi
description: The name of the restaurant derives from the location of owner-chef Kazuaki Baba’s restaurant in Takagamine, an area formerly known as Otagi County. “Since you took the trouble to come all this way…” is a favoured phrase with which he welcomes patrons. The exuberant uniqueness of the menu delights diners, with offerings such as duck charcoal-grilled on low heat, cream croquettes of fugu shirako, and dandan noodles à la mode japonais of hand-made udon.

name: Shunsaiten Tsuchiya
description: Osaka is a textile production centre, and Yukihiko Tsuchisaka says he uses cottonseed oil to contribute to the wellbeing of his hometown. Watching him put his all into the deep-frying, mindful of all the effort that went into producing the ingredients, is a wonderful sight. He is thorough in his preparations, adjusting the batter and the way he deep-fries, and even changing the sourness of the dipping sauce, according to the weather and ingredients. He puts to work the sensibilities he cultivated in the field of general Japanese cuisine in making the tempura and beautifully arranged hassun.

name: Ogata
description: Having your fill of Japanese cuisine stripped to its essentials, and lovingly served on antique and contemporary dishware, is the real pleasure of Ogata. Owner-chef Toshiro Ogata fills each plate with nature’s bounty. “Holding back on seasonings richly draws out the innate flavours of the ingredients”, he explains.
